critique: This document, an executive order from 1962, focuses on employee-management relations within the Federal service. It grants federal employees the right to form and join employee organizations, and outlines different levels of recognition (informal, formal, exclusive) for these organizations. It also establishes procedures for consultation and negotiation between agencies and employee representatives. The order emphasizes the importance of orderly and constructive relationships between employee organizations and management officials. It also creates a temporary committee to oversee the implementation of the order. The order also explicitly states that it does not allow striking or advocating for the overthrow of the government. It also states that it does not allow discrimination based on race, color, creed, or national origin. It also states that management retains the right to direct employees, hire, promote, transfer, assign, and retain employees, and to suspend, demote, discharge, or take other disciplinary action against employees. It also states that management retains the right to relieve employees from duties because of lack of work or for other legitimate reasons. It also states that management retains the right to maintain the efficiency of the Government operations entrusted to them. It also states that management retains the right to determine the methods, means and personnel by which such operations are to be conducted. It also states that management retains the right to take whatever actions may be necessary to carry out the mission of the agency in situations of emergency. It also states that agreements entered into with employee organizations may contain provisions for the arbitration of grievances, but such arbitration shall be advisory in nature with any decisions or recommendations subject to the approval of the agency head. It also states that the Civil Service Commission shall establish and maintain a program to assist in carrying out the objectives of this order. It also states that the head of each agency, in accordance with the provisions of this order and regulations prescribed by the Civil Service Commission, shall extend to all employees in the competitive civil service rights identical in adverse action cases to those provided preference eligibles under section 14 of the Veterans' Preference Act of 1944, as amended. It also states that nothing in this order shall be construed to annul or modify, or to preclude the renewal or continuation of, any lawful agreement heretofore entered into between any agency and any representative of its employees. Nor shall this order preclude any agency from continuing to consult or deal with any representative of its employees or other organization prior to the time that the status and representation rights of such representative or organization are determined in conformity with this order. It also states that the order does not apply to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Central Intelligence Agency, or any other agency, or to any office, bureau or entity within an agency, primarily performing intelligence, investigative, or security functions if the head of the agency determines that the provisions of this order cannot be applied in a manner consistent with national security requirements and considerations. When he deems it necessary in the national interest, and subject to such conditions as he may prescribe, the head of any agency may suspend any provision of this order with respect to any agency installation or activity which is located outside of the United States. Ideological Tilt: The order leans slightly liberal (+2) as it promotes collective bargaining and employee rights, which are generally associated with left-leaning policies. Immigration Approach: This order does not address immigration, so it is neutral (0). Executive Power: The order could be seen as somewhat limiting executive power (-1) as it establishes a framework for employee-management relations that requires consultation and negotiation. However, it also reserves significant management rights. Federalism: The order strengthens the federal government's role in regulating employee-management relations within federal agencies (+1), thus centralizing power. National Security vs. Civil Liberties: The order seems to strike a balance (0). It aims to improve working conditions for federal employees, but also includes provisions to ensure government efficiency and national security. Economic Regulation: The order has a moderate interventionist approach (+1) as it establishes a framework for collective bargaining and regulates employee-management relations. Social Inclusion: The order promotes social inclusion (+1) by prohibiting discrimination based on race, color, creed, or national origin in employee organizations.
